title-group.article-title: Lissencephaly and Band Heterotopia: LIS1, TUBA1A, and DCX Mutations in Hungary

abstract.p: The spectrum of lissencephaly ranges from absent (agyria) or decreased (pachygyria) convolutions to less severe malformation known as subcortical band heterotopia. Mutations involving LIS1 and TUBA1A result in the classic form of lissencephaly, whereas mutations of the DCX gene cause lissencephaly in males and subcortical band heterotopia in females. This report describes the clinical manifestations and imaging and genetic findings in 2 boys with lissencephaly and a girl with subcortical band heterotopia. An ovel mutation (c.83_84delAT, p.Tyr28Phefs*31) was identified in LIS1 in 1 of the boys with lissencephaly and another novel mutation (c.200delG, p.Ile68Leufs*87) was found in DCX in the girl with subcortical band heterotopia. The mutations appeared in the first half of the genes and are predicted to result in truncated proteins. A mutation was found in the TUBA1A gene (c.1205G>A, p.Arg402His) in the other boy. This mutation affects the folding of tubulin heterodimers, changing the interactions with proteins that bind microtubules.

body.p: Neuronal migration consists of nerve cells moving from their site of origin in the ventricular and subventricular zones to their final location to form proper neural circuits.1 It is a highly complex process involving an assortment of chemical signals that direct neurons to specific brain regions.2

Disorders of neuronal migration are a heterogeneous group of disorders of nervous system development. One of the most significant among these is lissencephaly, characterized by paucity of normal gyri and sulci resulting in a “smooth brain.” Its birth prevalence is estimated 1:85 000.3 Affected children have early developmental delay, mental retardation, cerebral palsy, and epilepsy.4 The spectrum of lissencephaly ranges from absent (agyria) or decreased (pachygyria) convolutions to less severe malformations known as subcortical band heterotopia.5 Subcortical band heterotopia is defined as a cluster of normal neurons in abnormal locations with the main presenting features of seizures and variable degrees of cognitive and motor impairment. Cognitive function in neuronal migration disorders varies from normal to severe retardation and correlates well with the thickness of the band and the degree of pachygyria.4 The imaging findings of lissencephaly vary with the severity of mutation.6 When very severe, the cortex is markedly thickened and almost no sulci are formed; when less severe, the cortex is less thickened and a variable number of shallow sulci separate broad gyri. In classic lissencephaly, cortical thickness is increased 4-fold and there is a recognizable gradient in which the malformation is more severe anteriorly (DCX) or posteriorly (LIS1 and TUBA1A).4 The most important genes responsible for migrational defects are LIS1, DCX, TUBA1A,7 and ARX. 8 Codeletion of the LIS1 and YWHAE genes results in Miller-Dieker syndrome.4

LIS1 gene maps to chromosome 17p13.3 and encodes the β (regulatory) subunit of the brain isoform of platelet activating factor acetylhydrolase (PAFAH1B1).5 Mutations of LIS1 result in the classic form of lissencephaly with smooth and thick cortex. DCX is located on Xq22.3-q23 and encodes a protein named doublecortin.5 Mutations of DCX have been observed in lissencephaly in boys and subcortical band heterotopia in girls. TUBA1A maps to chromosome 12q13.12 and encodes the microtubule protein α-1a tubulin. Mutations of TUBA1A result in classical lissencephaly with microcephaly, agenesis of the corpus callosum, and cerebellar hypoplasia.7

We present the cytogenetic and molecular genetic studies of 3 Hungarian children affected by neuronal migration disorder (2 with lissencephaly and 1 with subcortical band heterotopia). Diagnostic algorithm according to Cardoso et al9 was followed, and in 2 of the 3 patients, novel mutations in LIS1 and DCX genes were detected. A mutation in the TUBA1A gene was found in the third patient.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Three children with neuronal migration disorders were studied: 2 boys aged 9 and 3 years with lissencephaly and 1 girl aged 11 years with subcortical band heterotopia. All patients were born at term to unrelated, healthy parents, after uneventful pregnancies, with normal birth weight (3010 g, 3900 g, and 3550 g, respectively) and normal Apgar scores.

Patient 1 (male) had multifocal clonic seizures in the neonatal period. The electroencephalograph (EEG) revealed depression of the background activity and asynchronous epileptic discharges bilaterally over the central and occipital regions. The seizures were poorly controlled by phenobarbital. Infantile spasms appeared in infancy and the EEG showed hypsarrhythmia. West syndrome was diagnosed and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) treatment started. He responded to ACTH; however, partial seizures recurred later, which proved to be resistant to valproate, carbamazepine, and phenytoin. Motor and intellectual development was severely delayed.

On examination at the age of 9 years, the patient’s head circumference was 49.5 cm (3rd percentile). Nystagmiform eye jerks were observed and he was unable to follow objects. He was not able to respond to auditory stimuli and was nonverbal. Severe generalized hypotonia with brisk tendon reflexes and ankle clonus were observed with lack of motor development. He had partial seizures daily and multifocal clonic jerks unresponsive to valproate, phenytoin, and ketogenic diet. The EEG showed diffuse slowing and bilateral spike and wave discharges.

Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) performed at 2 months of age revealed smooth brain surface and shallow, vertically oriented sylvian fissures. A thin outer cortical layer was separated from a thick deeper cortical layer by a zone of white matter. The agyria–pachygyria seemed to be more severe in the posterior areas than anteriorly (Figure 1). The cerebrum showed a figure-of-eight appearance on axial images. Myelin formation was not recognizable in the centrum semiovale. The corpus callosum, brainstem, and cerebellum were normal.

caption.p: Axial T2-weighted magnetic resonance image (MRI) of patient 1 at the age of 2 months. Anterior pachygyria and almost complete posterior agyria can be observed. The cerebral cortex is thick, and a thin outer layer is separated by white matter from a broad layer of arrested neurons. The brain has a figure 8 appearance.

sec.p: Patient 2 (male) showed the following leading symptoms: microcephaly (head circumference was 37 cm at birth and 41 cm at the age of 3 years), delayed motor and mental development, and infantile spasms. Ictal EEG showed bilateral, symmetrical 4- to 16-Hz rhythm, generalized spike-waves, and bursts in sleep. Vigabatrin therapy was effective, and the infantile spasms disappeared. Convulsions and seizures were not observed. Complex rehabilitation treatment is continuous. Presently the patient can walk with help; he has minimal speech competency.

Brain MRI performed at 6 days of age revealed agyria and pachygyria predominantly affecting the posterior areas (Figure 2) accompanied by corpus callosum agenesis and cerebellar vermis hypoplasia. The anterior limb of the internal capsule was not recognizable and the basal ganglia were poorly separated.

caption.p: Axial T2-weighted magnetic resonance image (MRI) of patient 2 at the age of 6 days shows complete agyria.

sec.p: Patient 3 (female) showed delayed motor and mental development: she could walk at 18 months and speak a few words by the age of 3.5 years. Epileptic seizures, such as brief episodes of tonic–clonic convulsions on awakening, appeared at 18 months. EEG examination showed epileptiform discharges bilaterally over the frontal and temporal areas. The seizures were well controlled by carbamazepine. At the age of 7 years she had difficulties with reading and writing. The psychological examination revealed an IQ of 70.

Brain MRI (Figure 3) at 7 years of age revealed a thick homogeneous band of gray matter separated from the lateral ventricles and the cerebral cortex by layers of normal-appearing white matter (subcortical band heterotopia). The band was complete, surrounding the central white matter. The sulci were shallow. The corpus callosum, brainstem, and cerebellum were normal.

caption.p: Axial T2-weighted (A) and coronal T1-weighted (B) magnetic resonance images (MRI) of patient 3 show a continuous wide layer of heterotopic gray matter separated from the cortex by a layer of myelinated white matter. The cortex is mildly pachygyric.

sec.title: Genetic Analysis
sec.p: Peripheral lymphocytes were cultured with phytohemagglutinin for 72 hours, and GTG-banded chromosome analysis was performed according to standard cytogenetic protocols. Results were described according to the International System for Human Cytogenetic Nomenclature (ISCN 2009).10 Fluorescent in situ hybridization was performed on interphase cells to detect Miller-Dieker (17p13)/Smith-Magenis (17p11) microdeletion syndromes using region-specific probes (Abbott/Vysis, Chicago, Illinois, USA) according to the manufacturer’s protocols. The images were captured by Zeiss Axioplan2 (Carl Zeiss, Brussels) fluorescence microscope and analyzed by ISIS software (Metasystems, Germany).
Genomic DNA was extracted from peripheral blood leukocytes using QiaAmp DNA mini kit (Qiagen, Germany) according to the manufacturer’s protocol.

The entire coding region of the LIS1 (OMIM*601545, exons 2-11), DCX (OMIM*300121, exons 4-9), and TUBA1A (OMIM*602529, exons 1-4) genes and at least 30 base pairs of intronic flanking sequence, 50 base pairs of sequence 5′ of the first coding exon, and at least 100 base pairs after the stop codon were amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

LIS1 PCR conditions were as follows: 50-μL reaction containing 100 ng DNA, 0.2 mM dNTP, 0.2 μM of each primer11 (Table 1), and 2.5 U of DreamTaq DNA polymerase (Fermentas, Canada) in standard 10× PCR buffer. DCX PCR assays were performed by using 150 ng DNA, 0.2 mM dNTP, 0.25 μM of each primer5 (Table 2), and 2.5 U of DreamTaq DNA polymerase in standard 10× PCR buffer. Reactions were performed in MJ Mini Thermal Cycler (Biorad, Hercules, California, USA). Thermocycling parameters were as follows: an initial denaturing cycle at 95°C for 7 minutes followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 95°C for 30 seconds, annealing at melting temperatures (Tables 1 and 2) for 30 seconds, and extension at 72°C for 30 seconds. A final extension step of 72°C for 7 minutes was used. The PCR products were separated by electrophoresis in a 3% agarose gel. The amplified genomic DNA fragments were purified according to the manufacturer’s guide (QIAquick PCR purification kit, Qiagen, Germany). The purified PCR products were sequenced by standard protocol using BigDye Terminator v3.1 Cycle Sequencing kit (Applied Biosystems, Carlsbad, California, USA). The samples were analyzed on 4-capillary 3100-Avant Genetic Analyzer (Applied Biosystems, Carlsbad, California, USA). The DNA fragments were separated on POP6 polymer (Applied Biosystems, Carlsbad, California, USA). TUBA1A PCR conditions, primer sequence, thermocycling parameters, and sequence analysis have been previously described.7 We described the mutations according to the standard mutation nomenclature.12

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Cytogenetic analysis revealed normal karyotypes in all 3 patients, and fluorescent in situ hybridization analysis did not reveal microdeletion of the Miller-Dieker or Smith-Magenis regions in any of them.

In patient 1, the LIS1 and DCX genes were sequenced and a 2–base pair novel mutation (Figure 4A) in exon 3 of the LIS1 gene (c.83_84delAT) was found. The mutation is predicted to result in a frame shift and a truncated protein (p.Tyr28Phefs*31), consisting of 31 amino acids, instead of 409 amino acids of the normal LIS1 protein. The mutation was not found in either of the patient’s parents, confirming de novo origin in the patient (Figure 4B).

caption.p: Partial LIS1 gene sequence electropherogram of patient 1 shows the 2–base pair deletion (c.83_84delAT) causing a frameshift mutation (A). The LIS1 gene sequence electropherogram of parents of patient 1 is normal (B).

sec.p: In patient 2, mutation analysis in the LIS1, DCX, and TUBA1A genes revealed a base pair substitution in exon 4 of the TUBA1A gene (c.1205G>A). This mutation is a transition resulting in an amino acid change (p.Arg402His). The mutation was not found in either of the patient’s parents, confirming de novo origin in the patient. The mutant protein model has been previously described.13

In patient 3, only the DCX gene was sequenced, and she was found to be heterozygous for the mutation c.200delG (Figure 5A) in exon 4 of the DCX gene (Figure 5B shows the normal sequence of this exon). This mutation is predicted to result in a truncated protein (p.Ile68Leufs*87), consisting of 87 amino acids instead of the 365 amino acids of the normal protein. The patient’s parents declined testing.

caption.p: Partial DCX gene sequence electropherogram of patient 2 shows a single base pair deletion, c.200delG, causing a frame shift mutation (A) in contrast with the normal DCX gene sequence (B).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: About 60% of patients with lissencephaly carry genomic alterations or mutations in the LIS1 gene.14,15 Most mutations (84%) are truncating mutations, affecting the coiled-coil domain of the gene and causing a more severe phenotype than similar mutations in the downstream regions.9 Intragenic deletions and duplications of LIS1 extending from single-exon deletions or duplications to deletions of the entire coding region have also been described.15,16 Most LIS1 intragenic mutations are of de novo origin.

The main functional domains of the encoded protein are a LisH motif at the N terminal, followed by a coiled-coil region and 7 WD40 repeats at the C terminal.17,18 The LisH domain, coiled-coil domain, and WD40 repeats are important for dimerization, are involved in protein/protein interactions, and are essential for LIS1 protein function.19
–24 The LIS1 protein has 2 main functions: first, it regulates the level of platelet activating factor in the brain whose function is thought to be critical for correct neuronal migration.25,26 Second, it is known to play a central role in the organization of the cytoskeleton by interacting with several proteins such as tubulin as well as proteins associated with the centrosome and involved in microtubule dynamics, affecting neuronal proliferation and migration.27
–31
Mutations in LIS1 result in a reduction in the amount of correctly folded LIS1 protein.19 An abnormal LIS1 gene product disrupts the production and migration of neurons in the developing brain.32

The novel mutation of LIS1 (c.83_84delAT) in patient 1 in our study resulted in a truncated protein (Tyr28Phefs*31). The mutant protein is predicted to contain 31 amino acids instead of the normal LIS1 protein with 409 amino acids (7.6%). The coiled-coil domain and the 7 WD40 repeats in the protein are predicted to be deleted. The mutant protein causes a severe lissencephaly phenotype as a result of a substantially truncated protein.

Mutations of DCX have been found in all familial cases of subcortical band heterotopia reported till now and in 80% of sporadic females and 25% of sporadic males with attenuated phenotype due to X-chromosome inactivation in females and in classic, severe form in hemizygous males. Maternal germline or mosaic DCX mutations may occur in about 10% of cases,33 but most cases result from de novo mutations.34 –36 The DCX gene’s product, doublecortin, is a cytosolic microtubule-binding protein containing 2 conserved tandemly organized 80–amino acid microtubule-binding domains37,38 with several potential regions for regulation by phosphorylation and for protein interactions. It is thought to promote elongation and stabilization of the microtubule network within the leading process of neuroblasts during migration.38 Phosphorylation of DCX protein alters its interaction with microtubules and thereby probably its function as well.

The Ile68Leufs*87 (c.200delG) mutation in doublecortin in this study results in truncation of the protein. The abnormal protein is predicted to consist of 87 amino acids in contrast to the 365 amino acids of the normal protein (24%) disturbing the normal function. The C terminal end of this protein is predicted to be absent, so the regulation of doublecortin activity by phosphorylation and the protein stability are disturbed. Given the absence of the C-terminal DCX domain, the protein is unable to bind to tubulin and disturb the microtubule network in the process of neuroblast migration.

About 4% of patients with lissencephaly carry mutations in the TUBA1A gene; mutations in this gene are a relatively rare cause of classical lissencephaly.7 Poirier et al39 identified de novo heterozygous TUBA1A mutations in patients with a wide spectrum of brain dysgenesis, ranging from agyria to laminar heterotopia. Retrospective examination of brain MRI showed defects in the cerebellum, hippocampus, corpus callosum, and brainstem. Gyral malformations were more severe in the posterior than anterior brain regions.39

Morris-Rosendahl et al7 identified 4 different TUBA1A mutations in 5 of 46 patients with variable patterns of lissencephaly on brain MRI. Four of the 5 patients had congenital microcephaly, and all had dysgenesis of the corpus callosum, cerebellar hypoplasia, and variable cortical malformations, including subtle subcortical band heterotopia and absence or hypoplasia of the anterior limb of the internal capsule.7

α-Tubulin and β-tubulin heterodimers assemble to form microtubules that are essential for neuronal migration, neurite extension, and nucleokinesis. The pattern of expression of TUBA1A is limited to early-born postmitotic migrating neurons throughout development and to specific neurogenetic regions in the adult brain.13

The Arg402His (c.1205G>A) mutation in patient 2 mutates a highly conserved arginine residue to a histidine at the beginning of the H11-H12 loop near the interface of the protein. It is possible that this mutation affects the folding of tubulin heterodimers and may also influence interactions with microtubule-binding proteins such as doublecortin and kinesin KIF1A.13 The patient shows lissencephaly associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum, vermis hypoplasia, and abnormalities of the internal capsule.
Based on our search of the Human Gene Mutation Database/Biobase,40 both mutations in the LIS1 and DCX genes found in 2 of our 3 patients are novel mutations.

In the 3 patients with neuronal migration disorders described in this study, mutation analysis was performed in LIS1, TUBA1A, and DCX based on the MRI findings. To optimize molecular genetic analysis of patients with lissencephaly and subcortical band heterotopia, it is essential to be able to clearly define the phenotype.
